description:
Starmerella bacillaris is a species of yeast that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a member of the genus Starmerella, which is a group of related yeast species commonly found in various environments, including soil, water, and the gastrointestinal tract of animals.

Starmerella bacillaris is known to be a haploid, unicellular organism that reproduces asexually through budding. The cells are typically ovoid or ellipsoidal in shape and can range in size from approximately 3 to 6 micrometers in diameter.

This yeast species is capable of fermenting a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, sucrose, and maltose, and can produce ethanol as a byproduct of this process. Starmerella bacillaris has been studied for its potential applications in the food and beverage industries, as well as its role in the natural fermentation of certain foods and beverages.

The ecology and distribution of Starmerella bacillaris are not fully understood, but it is known to be widely distributed and can be found in various environmental niches. Further research is needed to fully elucidate the biology, diversity, and potential applications of this yeast species.
